Research & Projects

Advancing the frontiers of computational mathematics and quantitative finance through innovative research.

dS/S = μdt + σdW

Geometric Brownian Motion - Foundation of Modern Finance

∂ Current Research

Machine Learning Applications in Quantitative Finance

Developing novel deep learning architectures for option pricing and risk management. This research focuses on creating neural network models that can efficiently price complex derivatives while maintaining mathematical rigor.

Stanford University | 2024 - Present

Computational Methods for Stochastic Differential Equations

Investigating high-performance numerical methods for solving SDEs in financial modeling. Working on improving the efficiency and accuracy of Monte Carlo simulations for derivative pricing and risk assessment.

Stanford University | 2024 - Present

∫ Publications & Papers

"Deep Learning Approaches to Option Pricing: A Comparative Study"

Under Review - International Journal of Financial Engineering

A comprehensive analysis of various neural network architectures for derivative pricing, comparing traditional methods with modern deep learning approaches.

"Computational Efficiency in Monte Carlo Methods for Financial Risk"

In Preparation - Computational Finance Conference 2024

Novel variance reduction techniques for Monte Carlo simulations in high-dimensional financial problems.

λ Projects

Algorithmic Trading System

Developed a machine learning-based trading algorithm using reinforcement learning techniques. The system incorporates real-time market data analysis and risk management protocols.

Technologies: Python, TensorFlow, NumPy, Pandas

Option Pricing Calculator

Built a comprehensive option pricing tool implementing Black-Scholes, binomial trees, and Monte Carlo methods. Features interactive visualization of Greeks and sensitivity analysis.

Technologies: C++, Python, MATLAB, React

Risk Management Dashboard

Created a real-time portfolio risk monitoring system with VaR calculations, stress testing capabilities, and regulatory compliance reporting.

Technologies: Python, SQL, Flask, D3.js

Stochastic Process Simulator

Developed a high-performance simulation engine for various stochastic processes used in quantitative finance, with GPU acceleration for large-scale computations.

Technologies: C++, CUDA, Python, OpenMP

∑ Conferences & Presentations

SIAM Conference on Financial Mathematics & Engineering

Presented research on "Neural Networks in Derivative Pricing"

Philadelphia, PA | June 2024

International Conference on Computational Finance

Poster presentation on "Monte Carlo Variance Reduction Techniques"

London, UK | September 2024

Stanford Graduate Research Symposium

Keynote presentation on "The Future of Quantitative Finance"

Stanford, CA | March 2024

∞ Future Directions

My research roadmap focuses on the convergence of artificial intelligence and quantitative finance. I am particularly interested in developing interpretable AI models for financial decision-making, exploring quantum computing applications in portfolio optimization, and creating more robust risk management frameworks for emerging financial instruments.

E[max(S_T - K, 0)] = S_0Φ(d_1) - Ke^(-rT)Φ(d_2)

Black-Scholes Formula - The cornerstone of modern derivatives pricing
